Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2016 09:01AM - edited Oct 23, 2016 09:04AM by Oncearunneralwaysarunner Hi there, I buy my sleeves and gloves from Certicare (http://certicare.ca) in Ottawa. I usually pick them up in person but I do know they ship orders too. They carry a few brands as well. They do fittings as well so it might be worth it for your friend to take a drive if she can, it's about 2 hours from Montreal. The staff is really good. Now that I've been fitted, they have my info on file and I just email to place my order and they make sure I have the right size. They have shipped me orders when I was unable to make it in to pick up my order. Perhaps that could be an option for your friend. Or Certicare might be able to recommend a fitter in Montreal that offers similar services. Oh and I forgot to add, they are really good with replacing garments that might have issues with them. I had a problem with the last gloves I ordered and they worked with the company to get me replacements. Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: Mail-order or online garment suppliers in Canada? carol57 She

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2013 03:58PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Thanks everyone for your kind words of encouragement and support. Starting to feel really nervous about tomorrow. I now know the time of my surgery and the time I have to be at the hospital for which makes this so much more real. Time to pack my very small bag, if all goes well it is day surgery and I'll be home to sleep. I managed to get everything I wanted to do done, well almost everything but what is not done can wait. Hezzer - you may want to read "Salt Sugar Fat" by Michael Moss. I recently read this book and loved it. It looks at the processed food industry and looks at the history of the large food corporations, how food is produced now a days and what it contains and how sugar, fat and salt are added to foods and how it makes us crave those products more, therefore resulting in more sales. Corpor and Warrior_woman - I'm glad I'm not the only one who has the itch to get out there for a run. My running took a back seat during chemo and I was just getting into a routine again only to be laid up for a while. Chemo took a lot out of me and I have to rebuild from scratch. Hopefully we won't get too much snow this winter and getting the runs in will be easier. I'm thinking I need a big, audacious goal such as running the Dopey Challenge in January 2015 to get me fully motivated again. For everyone having surgery this week, all the best and my thoughts are with you. Hopefully the meds will wear off soon enough and I'll be back to posting soon.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 05:16AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Big, gentle left sided hugs to all of you going for surgery today. You can do it, you are all strong. Thinking of you today. Big, even gentler (is that even a word?!?) hugs to those who have had surgery and are recovering. Wishing you speedy, relatively pain free recoveries. I'm back home, got back on late Monday night. So far all is going well. There were no surprises with surgery. We just have to wait for the pathology results. Pain is well under control. I had a few Percocets yesterday but no where near as much as I was allowed. I'm going to try sticking to Tylenol today. My ice packs have been a godsend. A big thanks to all the ladies who provided post-op tips. Thanks to those I rushed out on Sunday and got a couple of button down shirts. So thankful I had those, I don't think I can get a regular shirt over my head. Genie bras (or in my case knock off) are great. I had a couple at home already and they have been really good. I've been sleeping on the couch propped up by pillows and based on last night I think I'll be going back to my regular bed tonight. Time to go and sit with my ice pack!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2013 06:13AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Vikki and Claire - so sorry to hear about the losses you have suffered recently, my thoughts are with you during this difficult time. Laurievp, hezzer and lydia - all the best of luck tomorrow. You are strong and will get through it with flying colours :) On the recovery front, things are going pretty well. I have bit of pain in my arm pit but I had a full node dissection so that is to be expected. The nerve pain going up and down my arm has been interesting. It's not constant but feels like I'm getting acupuncture. My range of motion is slowly coming back but in the mean time I have named my right arm Rex for T-Rex as it does feel like it is a t-Rex arm! That then evolved to my left arm being called Norm for normal since it has full range of motion. Yep, I have a twisted sense of humour!

Velle - good luck today, I'm sure you will see this post later, I'm a little late today trinitymorning and 2ndtime - all the best for tomorrow I think I'll take a walk outside this afternoon, there is a beautiful sun out there so it probably means it's really cold. I'll just have to wear a really warm hat!

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2013 05:48PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I had/have the same thing. Lots of swelling in my armpit and it it's really hard. In my case it's a seroma, basically a buildup of fluid. Last week I could not put my arm down beside me because it was so swollen, it looked like I was trying to imitate the Hulk but only on that side. I saw my surgeon and he drained it in his office. It did not hurt and he took out almost a cup of fluid. I felt so much better after. I have a bit of swelling now but no where near as much.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 04:38PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Cory - sorry to hear about the experience you had telling your friend about your diagnosis. Reading Cory's post and the others that followed made me realized that I always say "I was diagnosed with bc" never that I have it. I guess it allows me to be a bit more detached from it and allows me to get through it all while still getting on with life, this will get the best of me. I've also taken the approach that I don't care if people (other than immediate family and close friends) feel or react to my news. They might feel uncomfortable but that is for them to deal with, I have enough other things to get through myself that are a lot more serious and can't waste energy trying appease everyone. That may seem a bit harsh but it works for me.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 04:49AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Emla cream rocks! For those of you having chemo next and getting a port, it is well worth getting a tube. While getting the needle inserted into the port is not that painful, I hate needles and pain. The cream takes that pain away. It's an over the counter product in Canada, no need for a prescription, not sure about elsewhere. It's a little pricy, I know I had a sticker shock for the size of the tube, but so worth it especially with the year of Herceptin treatments. You have to put it on at least an hour before and put plenty on, I learned that lesson the hard way :) Hope everyone is recovering well, strength and positive thoughts to those who are having their surgeries in the next few days.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 05:15AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: if I may join in on the sports bra discussion, if you do high intensity activities I would recommend that you try a Shock Absorber bra and see if it works for you. They are a little pricy but they have a couple of models that you don't need to pull over your head. The model I use ties in the back with a regular bra closure and then one closure higher up to turn it into a racer back style. The straps are fully adjustable too. I usually tie the regular closure in the front and then roll it around before putting my arms through. Then I close the top. The only issue I have right now is with tying the top due to my limited range of motion in my right arm, it's a little harder than usual. The other nice thing is that the arm holes tend to be a little low so it doesn't hit my ALND incision. Hope everyone is having a good new year and best wishes, especially health for 2014.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2013 05:43AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: A small update from me, I finally got my pathology report back yesterday! I was getting really jealous of everyone who got theirs so quickly, it had been over two weeks for me. I had a pathologically complete response to chemo :D While I'm so happy about that, I'm still feeling blah. Heck, I was crying for no reason last night. I think it's because I know that I still have to go through radiation, Herceptin and tamoxifen even though it seems like the cancer is completely gone. I know there are a couple of you who had the same pathology results and I was wondering if you experienced the same thing? The healing is going well, except for the seroma I'm pretty much back to normal with some limited range of motion. I can drive again which is just wonderful. NJmom3 - some of the other ladies would be in a better position to let you know what to expect from a mastectomy, however you can take a read through the entire thread for great advise. Lots has already been posted during the month and that might answer some of your questions. I had a lumpectomy with axillary node dissection and my biggest limitation was the range of movement in my arm. I would plan to expect a quiet and cozy holiday. I was cooking a couple of days after surgery but nothing elaborate. We're doing a quasi pot-luck Christmas dinner at our house with family so that we don't have to cook as much. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2014 05:46AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: NJMom - I had neo-adjuvant chemo consisting of FEC-D and my hair started falling out about two weeks after my first treatment. It took about a week to fall out. I ended up getting it buzzed when it got really thin and wispy. I still had about 5-10% hair left on my head. I'm about two and a half months out from from my last treatment and it is slowly growing back, you can see less and less of my scalp as time goes by. When I run my hand over my head, I don't feel any scalp any more. As Sam2U mentioned, everyone reacts differently and there are different drugs with different side effects. The nurses at your cancer center might be the best to ask about your specific treatment and its side effects.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2014 02:10PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: hi stacy5971, I had nosebleeds with chemo, like you mostly when I blew my nose. I found my nose got dry and crusty leading to the nosebleeds.  I mentioned it to my MO and he recommended that I use Vaseline inside my nostrils and to let him know if it got worst. I ended up using a lubricating nasal spray and a humidifier at night. That kept things under control.
Posts.Title: bloody nose? stacey5971 stacey5971

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2014 03:21PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I too am an introvert, clearly confirmed by my Meyers-Briggs results, and I was fairly open with my diagnosis. I don't think there is a correlation between being introverted and the amount of people you tell, it's more of a comfort level thing. My husband and I are both only children so we told our parents, they in turn told our aunts and uncles. My friends were told, including Facebook friends. My social network is really small so most people I'm friends with on Facebook are those I do want to keep in touch with. As far as co workers I told my management team and those I worked closest with. I took a leave of absence and I didn't want people to speculate why I was off. I also told new people at work when I started back part time. Given that I work in a cube farm some people knew without even me telling them.  If I were to do it all over again, I'm not sure I would be as opened with people at work. Some people really have no boundaries and while no horrible situation happened, it wore me down to have to explain things to people. I also found co workers were the ones most likely to address the issue with "that tone". Maybe my friends just know better! One thing we did with friends that worked nicely was a periodic email update. Every time I had a chemo treatment, or major updates to provide, my husband would draft an email. I would review it then he would send it out. We were really open in those emails. That way everyone knew the same thing at the same time. What happened is that when I did meet up with friends my illness was not the subject of discussions. It allowed us to have our regular interactions.  I don't think there is a right or wrong with this. Go with what ever your gut tells you.
Posts.Title: When diagnosed- did you share with family & friends? MamaM whatnow

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 05:18AM - edited Mar 24, 2014 05:21AM by Oncearunneralwaysarunner hi blinds23, I'm triple positive and as Cowgirl13 mentioned, I also get Herceptin every three weeks for a year. I'm 31 and I have a three year old at home, she was 2 and a half when I started chemo. She would have grabbed at a PICC line. The nice thing with the port is that it's pretty much part of me and I can do what ever I want. Shower, swim, you name it. I don't have to worry about getting it caught on something or getting it wet (once it's healed). Having it accessed is easier than IV, there is no need to look for and find a vein. Once the needle is in, you don't feel it like you do with a IV needle. I wear tank tops all the time in the summer, and mostly scoop or v-neck shirts in the winter and my port shows. I can understand why you might be self conscious about it, I was a little when I first got it but It got to the point where it was too hot last summer and decided I was going to wear what was comfortable for me. All you see once the incision is healed is a small bump on my upper chest. I've never had anyone make comments about it, nor have it had anyone stare at it. I really don't notice it anymore, it's just there. Hope my experience helps provide some insight for when you make your decision. All the best with the upcoming treatments. Edited to add: chunky necklaces or scarfs are a great way to camouflage the port while still wearing tank tops :)
Posts.Title: Which treatment is better? Port or IV? blinds23 MellowYellow

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 04:45AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: ask your radiation oncologist and see if he or she approves having them removed. I asked mine about it at my follow up appointment and he said it was completely my choice. He told me that there was no more use for them from his perspective. Seems that different docs have different recommendations in this area.  I have not followed up yet on having them removed but will most likely look into it when the time feels right. The two dots between my breasts are large and seem off center to my body which bothers me more than the size. I can't see the ones on my sides so they don't bother me.
Posts.Title: Removal of rads tattoos Tink1966 Donna2012

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2014 08:51PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I wore things that I was comfortable in and that would leave my port available. This mostly consisted of yoga pants or leggings with tank tops or t-shirts that had a scoop neck so that my port was not under my clothes. I then wore a zip up sweater or hoodie to keep warm. The other thing that I brought with me was a quilt. Something to keep me warm that was from home, it just made me feel a bit more comfortable and that was a little less sterile than the whole chemo room.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 11:30PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: TeamKim and CruiserMay - whoo hoo on being done chemo, one last round of those nasty side effects and it's done. It's great to see the side effects ease up and know that you won't experience these again. I finally had my appointment with the RO yesterday. We finally have a plan in place for rads. I have my simulation on the 27th, an education session on January 7th and I start on January 13 for 6 weeks including the week of boosts. Looks like I'll be laying on my back with my arm up. I have a referral for physiotherapy to get the best range of motion in my arm before we start. I had surgery at the beginning of the month, and that's part of the reason why I'm starting in the 13th, give more time to get my arm back to normal. Safe travels for those of you traveling over the holidays, especially this weekend if you are in Eastern Ontario and surrounding areas. Nasty storms forecasted for the entire weekend.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 06:53AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Holeinone - sorry to hear that there appears to be a suspicious node. Hoping that it just looks suspicious, sending positive thoughts your way.  As for my surgical site issue, I have two incisions, one in my arm pit and one on the bottom of my breast. They put the wire on the incision on my breast for the CT scan and that showed up clear, it's just that he can't see from the scan where the internal work happened. Apparently it happens in about 20% of cases and could be related to the speed at which I healed. By not seeing where inside my breast tissue was taken out with certainly, he can't accurately target the boost. I meet with the other RO in two weeks and should find out more then. I'm feeling less anxious now that I have had my treatment. I don't do well with the unknown! It was painless and no skin issues yet but I know it's still really early in the process :) Now to eat my daily Cherry Blossom, I have a stash set up in a pyramid on my mantle as a makeshift advent calendar to count down treatments.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2014 06:55PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: for those looking for calendula cream, try your natural health food store. It's where I found mine and it was with the homeopathic products. I picked one with the least possible ingredients. My only complain is that it smells like dead flowers since there are no additional scents. I've also been using Glaxal Base cream as well. Again, not a fan of the smell but at least it doesn't smell like dead flowers! As for hair loss, I was informed that the hair loss is where you are being radiated. I'm looking forward to a hair free armpit! The hair on my head is growing in back slowly and doesn't seem to be affected by the radiation at all.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2013 09:14AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: count me in the gainers club. I gained about 25lbs since being diagnosed and doing chemo. My weight levelled off after chemo. Part of it was the steroids, part of it was the grazing to keep the nausea at bay and part of it was that I kept eating the same as I was when I was training for a marathon with the exception that barely had the energy to go for a walk. I'm now waiting until after the new year to get back into shape and better eating habits. No point with the holidays just around the corner. I love to bake and I'm not going to deprive myself of home baked cookies! SlowDeepBreaths - I too had a lumpectomy, but I don't have lumps near the incision on my breast. I do have a nice seroma (build up of fluid) in my armpit from the node dissection and my incision there looks lumpy. They did the stitches on the inside and I think that this is what I'm seeing. Maybe it's something similar in your case?

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 08:02AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: msmaples - thanks for the heads up about coffee. I'll know to expect it now. The lack of taste buds just might make it a little easier on my wallet :) Is anyone using, or been advised to use Glaxal Base cream or calendula cream twice daily during treatment? I have a sample of the Glaxal Base and while unscented it stinks. I'm wondering if anyone found the calendula cream to be the same.  sbp - I too don't deal well with changes to plans other unknown for that fact. If it's not within my control, I try to not stress over it. That's the hard part. If there is something within my control then I do what ever I can to make things move faster. Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 11:58PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: TeamKim - no reduction for me at the time of the lumpectomy, just a straight removal of the affected tissue. How it was explained to me is that there will often be a buildup of fluid where they took out the tissue and that is what they look for on the CT to identify the area to target for the boost. I didn't have that pocket of fluid buildup which made it hard to identify the site.  LanaM - guess what I was thinking about when I was laying there yesterday? Yep, the cost of the machine. The tech told me that the particular machine I'm using is advanced and that they got the "upgrades" on it. I had to wonder if it was more or less than the price tag you we're told!

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2013 11:20PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Good morning everyone, hope you are all doing well and surviving the holidays! :) I've been reading all of your posts, just have not had time to post back then needed to cool off after my CT simulation was postponed on Friday. Sorry if this is a bit of a rant. I was all ready and set to get moving forward and it has been rescheduled. I got all the way to being placed on the table and into position only for the tech to notice the nice huge seroma I have in my armpit where the lymph nodes were taken out. After discussions with another tech and the RO on call that day, it was decided that it would best to do the scan after I have the seroma drained. Any changes in the contour of your body affect the way you receive the actual radiation and impacts the plans they develop. I'm rescheduled for my simulation for the 6th of January but I somehow have to manage to reach my surgeon's office to have this thing drained before the 6th which I expect to be a challenge due to the holidays. As of right now my treatment is not being delayed but it might if the scan has to be pushed back.  I noticed some of you mentioned wanting to lose the extra chemo weight, I do too but I've been advised to wait until radiation is finished to drop it. It's for the same reasons as why they are not doing my simulation yet, any changes in your body contour affects treatment. I have about 25lbs to lose and was hoping to get going on that so that I could avoid having to buy new clothes in a bigger size to go back to work. I can work out but I've been advised against actively losing weight. Good thing I can live in yoga pants and running gear, most of that still fits me due to the stretch in it! As for vitamins, I've been advised to stay away from vitamin A, C and E and any supplements containing anti-oxidants as that works against what radiation is doing. I haven't been told to stay away from much else.  On a positive note, my hair is growing back but really slowly. I had my last chemo treatment two months ago and you can still see scalp but it seems that there is a bit of hair all over my head right now. It's about half white and half brown but I'm normally a natural red head and way too young (31) to be having that much white hair! I'll be glad to have insulation on my head again, hats are great but I would like to sleep without a tuque :)
Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2014 11:34PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: RedReading - I'm in Ontario (being treated at the Ottawa Hospital) and I've been instructed to apply Glaxal Base Cream or Calendula cream three to four times a day from the get go. I've had my RO, nurse and techs remind me to do so. I was given written care instructions for my skin before starting radiation. 13/25 down, whoo hoo! My skin is holding up well, getting a bit itchy and red but not bad. I just have to remember not to scratch the right side. It is making me realize how much scratching an itch is instinctual  I've agreed to go ahead with the brachytherapy once external radiation is done for my boost. It's not scheduled yet but will be about one to two weeks after the end of radiation depending on how my skin is after it all. Not looking forward to the procedure but I was reassured that I'll be under some form of sedation for part of it, so that makes it easier to handle. Welcome to the new ladies and congrats to those who are done this week!
Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2014 08:13AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote:  lonnie713 - As far as I understand it, boost target the surgical site specifically and tends to be used when someone has a lumpectomy. When I first met with my RO before any treatment started we discussed doing 5 weeks of radiation if I had a mastectomy and 5 weeks plus a week of boosts if I had a lumpectomy. That being said, everyone's case is different. Some of the other ladies may have more information. As of today I have 6 treatments left! My skin is looking sunburnt but no blisters or any other issues other than being itchy. I have the cortisone cream but I find that it doesn't do much. According to the resident, the best way to stop the itching is to finish with treatment. I think I'll ask the techs this morning if there is anything else they would recommend, it's so hard not to scratch. I know that a fair bit of you have kept working during treatment but I was wondering if there is anyone else who is planning their return to work. I'm ready to start that plan and was wondering what others are doing. I'd love if anyone is willing to share :)
Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 03:41AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: My understanding about weight loss is that any weight loss, regardless of location could affect the plans they make for you. I was warned about loosing or gaining more than a couple of pounds because it changes your body's contour, not just your breast, and that could have an impact on how you line up on the machine and therefore affect where the radiation hits. I made sure to stay stable from the time I had my CT scan to my last treatment. My advice is to check with your team since we are all different and each doctor is different too.  Speaking of last treatment, I had my last external treatment on Friday. My skin help up pretty well, looks like a bad sunburn and feels like one too. I have a couple of little spots where the skin started to peel and is raw but no oozing. Now if I can only get the itching under control... Congrats to all others who wrapped up their treatments lately.
Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 02:15PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I'm 31 and was diagnosed in June. I had chemo prior to surgery and I too was able to achieve a complete pathological response. FEC-D eliminated all three tumours I had in my breast and the cancer that had traveled to my lymph nodes. here is my experience with FEC-D: overall I found the FEC much harder than the D. I was nauseous and slept for about a week with FEC but only had to deal with bone and muscle aches with the D. I also react strongly to medication that causes sleepyness and nausea so I'm sure that is just part of what is normal for me, not everyone is as fatigued as I am.  I would give the following advice based on my experience: 1. You might be sore after your port placement, if you have a port, it will go away in a couple of weeks. My neck and back were really stiff for a few days, then the soreness was just at the port site. 2. Emla cream is my friend! You can get it over the counter in Canada and it numbs the skin, put it on before going for a treatment and you won't feel the needle going in. 3. If you have your blood work done at a lab and not through your port, make sure to keep well hydrated and your arm and hand warm. It makes it easier to find a vein, my veins disappeared during chemo. 4. Take the anti-nausea meds and let your MO know if they don't work, I had to have mine constantly adjusted. 5. Take pain meds as prescribed when on the D. I was alternating between Advil and Tylenol every four hours and it worked great. I learned my lesson when I skipped a dose :) 6. Ask if they have hand and feet ice packs when on the D. I used them and it saved my nails. They are slightly more brittle than before but they look normal. Hope you have little side effects with chemo.
Posts.Title: Ladies in your 30's getting FEC-D protocol? calmandstrong robsp

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 06:56AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Hope everyone is doing well, I'm catching up on my reading and posting. calmandstrong - happy to hear that FEC is treating you decently and that you are starting to feel normal again. Mommy13 - good luck next week, we'll be thinking about you on the 27th. Jetnet91 - hope your side effects are manageable after your first treatment, they do wear off. About the "nesting", I had bouts of nesting before each treatment and yes, they felt like the nesting I went through when pregnant!  gonein40 - I know what you mean about the anxiety related to not knowing. I find what helps for me is to read as much as possible on a subject and be as prepared as possible. We each have our methods, I haven't tried the guided meditation/relaxation slv58 suggested but that seems like a very good idea and I will probably give it a try in the future. Brioche78 - I have a port, so I don't know how the D is on veins but overall I found the D easier than the FEC. Completely different side effects for me, I found it easier to deal with muscle and bone pain than with the fatigue and fog. Everyone is different though. Stay warm today.
Posts.Title: Ladies in your 30's getting FEC-D protocol? calmandstrong robsp

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2014 03:27PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: robsp - I started getting FEC side effects within about 4 hours of starting my treatment and they consisted of mild nausea and unbelievable fatigue that lasted for over a week. We all react differently so maybe you will have minimal side effects, let's hope that is the case :) As for the Nupegen, I was not taking it during FEC but did five injections with each of my docetaxel treatments. My blood work was within the margins my doctor established throughout my treatment, I don't know if he would have prescribed it during FEC if there would have been an increased risk for neutropenia.  Hope everyone's treatments are going as well as they can.

My oncologist says that things will go back to normal in a few months and not to rush out and get new glasses just yet. I'm hoping my vision will level out sooner rather than later.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2014 06:54AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Hi Quasi, I had a bit of that going on, my feet just felt really gross. I found it changed when I switched to the D, it went more to the tingling than the burning. I found that keeping my feet cool helped so did soaking in cold water. It was temporary relief but helped a bit. Make sure to mention that to your oncologist. When I did he told me to keep an eye on it and report if it got worst. If it had gotten worst he would have looked at adjusting the dosage. I'm almost four months out of chemo and the feeling has pretty much gone away. I get a bit of tingling in my big toes if I hit them against something but those residual side effects are pretty much gone.
Posts.Title: Ladies in your 30's getting FEC-D protocol? calmandstrong robsp

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2014 11:46PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: Positive thoughts to those starting radiation this week. I have my first treatment later this morning and I have this weird anxiety going on right now. I know that the side effects are most likely going to be easier than chemo based on the feedback here, but its the unknown factor that is getting to me. I had my CT simulation and tattoos, I have my potions and lotions to try and keep my skin nice and happy. I now know that I will only get 25 treatments as opposed to the 30 we were originally discussing. I'm getting my breast, axilla and clavicle area radiated.  I will not be getting the extra 5 boost treatments to the surgical site since it cannot be clearly identified on the CT scan and therefore my RO cannot accurately target the surgical site for the boost. I had a lumpectomy. Has anyone else experienced this? My RO is referring me to another RO who does brachytherapy as it may be possible to identify the surgical site by ultrasound and get the boost that way. I'll know more details when I meet with him or her.
Posts.Title: Winter 2013-2014 Rads TeamKim mouse9587

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2014 09:26AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I lost all my lashes with chemo, except about three hairs. I first tried a brow pencil but found that it clumped in my few remaining lashes and was just creepy. I ended up using SmashBox's Brow Tech with an angle brush (http://www.sephora.com/brow-tech-P260313?skuId=124... and I was pretty happy with it.  I liked that I could blend the two colours to give me something natural. I had two wigs that I barely wore but one was dark and one lighter so when I wore one, I could adjust my brow colour accordingly. As for the wax, I would tap my finger in it then tap my finger over my drawn on brow to help keep the power in place. I didn't like using the brush due to the clumping effect, and then my brush would be all waxy for the next application. Good luck finding something you like. Sephora is a good place to start :)
Posts.Title: Best Eyebrow kits /makeup if u have very little hair?? dancingdiva 208sandy

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2013 12:52PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: mommy0608 - I had a biopsy done in June of this year and while it wasn't fun, it's not major. I know there are different types of biopsies, however in my case the radiologist froze my breast, made a small incision and used a needle to go in and take a few samples of the lump. She used an ultrasound machine to find the lump and know where lump was. The samples were sent to the lab to be analyzed and I got my results a week later. I could not lift anything for two days and had to change a band-aid every day for 5 day. Hope this info helps.
Posts.Title: concerned but not diagnosed mommy0608 mommy0608

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 06:39PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: mommy0608 - I found a lump after rolling over in bed one night, feeling something odd and checking. That kicked started the whole process. I'm 31 with no other significant health issues and no history of breast cancer in my family, therefore no reason for regular mammogram screening. After seeing my family doctor, she referred me to breast health clinic. They did an ultrasound and mammogram on the same day. The radiologist had a look at my results, then did another ultrasound himself to confirm the tech's findings. Before I left the clinic that day, I had a appointment for the biopsy, an MRI and a follow-up with a surgeon to get my results. After getting copies of my results, the first set of imaging reported highly suspicious findings and was probably the reason why things went quickly. It was less than a month from the time I found the lump to the time i was diagnosed.
Posts.Title: concerned but not diagnosed mommy0608 mommy0608

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 08:40PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: The only thing I ever felt was the lump. I didn't have any pain or anything else. All I can say based on my experience is that if you think something is out of place have it checked out. There is a high likelihood that it's nothing major, but if it does turn out to be something the faster you can treat it, the better. I think the majority of us go to the worst case scenario spot, I do all the time but keep positive if you can. As far as treatment, I went with chemo first. Partly to shrink the tumours (I had three plus the lymph node) and partly to prevent any spread. Luckily there was no spread. I had my last chemo treatment on October 31. Chemo shrunk the tumours the the point where my pre-op MRI could not see anything, other than the marking clip that was put in. I'm so happy about that. I have surgery in two weeks and then radiation in the new year. Not the most fun I've had, but not as bad as I feared going into it.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2014 08:55AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I for one am happy to finally see something in the media that says that lumpectomies will give you the same survival odds as a BMX. Perhaps the angle taken by the author was a little abrasive and caused feathers to be ruffled. I'm not going to argue that and I respect what ever opinion one has on the article. There have been some very interesting discussions on another tread and there is validity to all opinions that were raised, in my humble opinion at least. To paraphrase what someone said in another discussion on this article, who's to say that any surgical option is the wrong approach to treating breast cancer? We are all unique, our diagnosis are all unique and all have our own reasons for choosing the path we choose. While this op-ed stated that BMX/CPM is the wrong approach to treat breast cancer, mainstream media is constantly implying that a lumpectomy is the wrong approach every single time they report that a celebrity has and a BMX and that they "did it to save my life and make sure that I'll be at my daughter's wedding". There is never a mention of the fact that statistically the odds of survival or the same, or discuss the reasons for picking one surgical route over another like we do on these boards. The articles never get down to that level of details. They simply imply that if you don't have a BMX you haven't done everything you could to save your life.  As a result, I'm tired of people who don't know any better question me on my choice of surgery or being asked why I did not do everything I could to beat this thing, or simply being given that look of "why would you not do everything to save your life?". People react that way because that is all they see in the media. I do use those opportunities to educate people but I'm also tired of defending my treatment choices. For anyone to imply that I didn't do everything and diminish my fight, or the fight of anyone else who has had a lumpectomy simply pisses me off. I had to vent, the whole issue about how media portrays breast cancer had been bothering me for a while.
Posts.Title: The Wrong Approach to Breast Cancer cp418 LissaSue22

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 08:15AM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: I'm also of the opinion that it's best to tell children age appropriate things. My daughter was 2 1/2 when I was diagnosed and she is now 4. She doesn't know that I had cancer but she knows that I had a booboo on my chest and that I had to have medicine and that medicine made me feel yucky. Similarly when I had surgery we told her I had a booboo and that she had to be extra gentle with me. Even at 2 1/2 she was picking up on things being a little off with me sleeping all the time due to chemo. We found that it worked well and we also only told her things as they were happening. We made sure to answer any questions she had in a way that she would understand. We took the same approach a few months back when my dad was diagnosed with brain cancer. She noticed the scar on his head from surgery and asked what it was. We told her that grandpa had a booboo and the doctors had to go and take it out, that they took it out. We haven't elaborated on what the actual diagnosis means but when we feel the time is right we will. Not sure if we will use the word cancer because she doesn't know what that means but we'll chat when my dad's health starts to impact his interactions with her. This is what makes sense for our family.
Posts.Title: Husband doesn't want to tell our 5 year old ChristaSea

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 12:13PM Oncearunneralwaysarunner wrote: speaking for myself only, the one last thing I would have wanted during active treatment is everyday use products that remind me that I'm in treatment. Based on that I'm not a fan of the proposed Chemo Care name. I do believe it is important to state and advertise that it is safe to use during treatment but the name itself should not reflect treatment itself. By giving it a more neutral, non chemo or treatment related name, you may also get more customers who are going to keep buying the product after their treatment and allows you to expand your market base. I'm going with the assumption that your products can also benefit people who are not undergoing chemo. Sorry I don't have any names to offer, I don't know enough about your products to provide valuable input.
Posts.Title: OT opinions needed on Skin care for chemo patients Cynbest Cynbest
